required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: Damage Control Laparotomy: A Randomized Controlled Trial

lead_sponsor.agency: The University of Texas Health Science Center, Houston

collaborator.agency: National Center for Advancing Translational Science (NCATS)

clinical_study.source: The University of Texas Health Science Center, Houston

brief_summary.textblock: Randomized study to compare outcomes of patients undergoing damage control laparotomies versus definitive closure for which there is surgeon equipoise to randomize.

detailed_description.textblock:
Single center, prospective, randomized study involving seriously injure patients requiring an emergent laparotomy within 90 minutes of arrival to the emergency department. There are situations in which the patient is unable to be closed at the end of the emergent laparotomy (identified as damage control) and there are situations in which the injury has been treated and the incision can be closed (definitive). There are also situations where it is not clear if the patient should be kept open or closed and the result of the surgery varies based on the surgeon performing the case.
The eligible subjects for this study will be randomized toward the end of the emergent laparotomy procedure on a 1:1 basis and will be followed throughout the hospitalization for complications. Patients will also be contacted at 6 month to complete a quality of life questionnaire.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants Who Died or Had Major Abdominal Complication (MAC)
primary_outcome.description: Major abdominal complication (MAC) is defined as development of an organ/space surgical site infection, enteric suture line failure, fascial dehiscence, or unplanned return to operating room (OR).

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Non-abdominal Morbidities
secondary_outcome.description: Non-abdominal Morbidities include Acute Kidney Failure, Deep Vein Thrombosis, Pulmonary Embolism, Pneumonia, and Urinary Tract Infection.
Number of days patient was not in hospital within the 30 day time frame.
Number of days patient not in the ICU during the 30 day time frame
Number of days patient not on ventilator in the 30 day time frame

secondary_outcome.measure: Patient-centered Outcomes Assessed Using the Standard Gamble
secondary_outcome.time_frame: at discharge from hospital (about 20 days after intervention)
secondary_outcome.description: Participants are asked to choose between two hypothetical outcomes: 1 - the sure outcome, that is, remaining in a state of ill health for a period of time; or 2 - the gamble, that is, choosing a medical intervention which has a certain probability of either restoring them to perfect health or killing them. The Standard Gamble identifies the probability (of the intervention delivering perfect health) at which the two alternatives (1 and 2) seem equally attractive. Scores range from 0% to 100%, with a score of 100% indicating that a choices 1 and 2 are equally attractive only when there is a 100% probability that the intervention will deliver perfect health, and a score of 0% indicating that choices 1 and and 2 are equally attractive even when there is a 0% probability that the intervention will deliver perfect health.

secondary_outcome.measure: Patient-centered Outcomes Assessed Using the Standard Gamble
secondary_outcome.description: Participants are asked to choose between two hypothetical outcomes: 1 - the sure outcome, that is, remaining in a state of ill health for a period of time; or 2 - the gamble, that is, choosing a medical intervention which has a certain probability of either restoring them to perfect health or killing them. The Standard Gamble identifies the probability (of the intervention delivering perfect health) at which the two alternatives (1 and 2) seem equally attractive. Scores range from 0% to 100%, with a score of 100% indicating that a choices 1 and 2 are equally attractive only when there is a 100% probability that the intervention will deliver perfect health, and a score of 0% indicating that choices 1 and and 2 are equally attractive even when there is a 0% probability that the intervention will deliver perfect health.

secondary_outcome.measure: Patient-centered Outcomes Assessed Using the 5-level European Quality of Life Scale-5D (EuroQol-5D-5L)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: at discharge from hospital (about 20 days after intervention)
secondary_outcome.description: The EuroQol-5D-5L assesses health-related quality of life. Total score ranges from 0 to 100, with 0 indicating the worst health imaginable and 100 indicating the best health imaginable.

secondary_outcome.measure: Patient-centered Outcomes Assessed Using the 5-level European Quality of Life Scale-5D (EuroQol-5D-5L)
secondary_outcome.description: The EuroQol-5D-5L assesses health-related quality of life. Total score ranges from 0 to 100, with 0 indicating the worst health imaginable and 100 indicating the best health imaginable.

secondary_outcome.measure: Patient-centered Outcomes Assessed Using the Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder Check List - Civilian (PCL-C)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: at discharge from hospital (about 20 days after intervention)
secondary_outcome.description: The PCL-C assesses Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) symptoms. Total score ranges from 17-85. A score of 17-29 shows little to no PTSD symptoms. A score of 28-29 indicates some PTSD symptoms. A score of 30-44 indicates moderate to moderately high severity of PTSD symptoms. A score of 45-85 indicates high severity of PTSD symptoms.

secondary_outcome.measure: Patient-centered Outcomes Assessed Using the Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder Check List - Civilian (PCL-C)
secondary_outcome.description: The PCL-C assesses Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) symptoms. Total score ranges from 17-85. A score of 17-29 shows little to no PTSD symptoms. A score of 28-29 indicates some PTSD symptoms. A score of 30-44 indicates moderate to moderately high severity of PTSD symptoms. A score of 45-85 indicates high severity of PTSD symptoms.

clinical_study.condition: Other Injury of Other Intra-abdominal Organs, Initial Encounter

arm_group.description: Subjects randomized to the definitive closure laparotomy arm will have the incision closed at the end of the exploratory laparotomy.

Subjects randomized to the damage control laparotomy arm will have the incision left open at the end of the exploratory laparotomy. The trauma team will evaluate the patient's clinical course to determine when the incision can be closed.

intervention.description: Subjects randomized to the definitive closure laparotomy arm will have the incision closed at the end of the exploratory laparotomy.

Subjects randomized to the damage control laparotomy arm will have the incision left open at the end of the exploratory laparotomy. The trauma team will evaluate the patient's clinical course to determine when the incision can be closed.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Emergent laparotomy
- Patient has injuries for which surgeon has equipoise to perform a Definitive (DEF) or Damage Control Laparotomy (DCL)
- Age ≥16 years (age cut-off for admission to adult trauma service at Memorial Hermann Hospital-Texas Medical Center)
Exclusion Criteria:
- Indication for DCL for which there is no surgeon equipoise:
- Need for gauze packing of liver or retroperitoneum for hemorrhage control
- Immediate need to go to Interventional Radiology for hemorrhage control
- Concern for Abdominal Compartment Syndrome - defined as physically unable to re-approximate fascia or >10mmHg change in peak airway pressure during fascial closure
- Hemodynamic instability - defined as persistent hypotension, ongoing transfusion requirement, or continuous vasopressor use
- Indication for DEF for which there is no surgeon equipoise:
- Negative and non-therapeutic laparotomies
- Isolated cystorrhaphy
- Prisoners
- Known pregnancy
- Patients with burns > 20% of total body surface area
- Patient/legally authorized representative opted out of exception from informed consent (opt out bracelet)
- Currently enrolled in another interventional study

overall_official.affiliation: The University of Texas Health Science Center, Houston

facility.name: Memorial Hermann Hospital - Texas Medical Center

reference.citation: Harvin JA, Podbielski J, Vincent LE, Fox EE, Moore LJ, Cotton BA, Wade CE, Holcomb JB. Damage control laparotomy trial: design, rationale and implementation of a randomized controlled trial. Trauma Surg Acute Care Open. 2017 Apr 13;2(1):e000083. doi: 10.1136/tsaco-2017-000083. eCollection 2017.

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: The University of Texas Health Science Center, Houston

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan

group.title: Total
group.description: Total of all reporting groups

measure.title: Grade of Liver Injury
measure.description: Grade ranges from 1 to 5, with a higher grade indicating worse injury

measure.title: Grade of Spleen Injury
measure.description: Grade ranges from 1 to 5, with a higher grade indicating worse injury

measure.title: Grade of Kidney Injury
measure.description: Grade ranges from 1 to 5, with a higher grade indicating worse injury

measure.title: Score on Abbreviated Injury Scale (AIS) - Head
measure.description: The AIS classifies individual injuries by body region as follows: 0 = No Injury; 1 = Minor; 2 = Moderate; 3 = Serious; 4 = Severe; 5 = Critical; 6 = Maximal (currently untreatable)

measure.title: Score on Abbreviated Injury Scale (AIS) - Chest
measure.description: The AIS classifies individual injuries by body region as follows: 0 = No Injury; 1 = Minor; 2 = Moderate; 3 = Serious; 4 = Severe; 5 = Critical; 6 = Maximal (currently untreatable)

measure.title: Score on Abbreviated Injury Scale (AIS) - Abdomen
measure.description: The AIS classifies individual injuries by body region as follows: 0 = No Injury; 1 = Minor; 2 = Moderate; 3 = Serious; 4 = Severe; 5 = Critical; 6 = Maximal (currently untreatable)

measure.title: Injury Severity Score (ISS)
measure.description: The Injury Severity Score (ISS) assesses the combined effects of injuries in multiple anatomical locations and ranges from from 1 to 75, with 75 being the most severe.

outcome.title: Number of Participants Who Died or Had Major Abdominal Complication (MAC)
outcome.description: Major abdominal complication (MAC) is defined as development of an organ/space surgical site infection, enteric suture line failure, fascial dehiscence, or unplanned return to operating room (OR).
outcome.population: Analysis is intention to treat, so all who were assigned to the intervention are analyzed, regardless of whether they received the intervention.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: Small sample size; failure to accrue targeted sample size of 56; inability to blind; imbalance of baseline characteristics in randomized arms

point_of_contact.name_or_title: John A. Harvin, MD, FACS, Associate Professor
point_of_contact.organization: The University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston
